columns.text: This exercise requires us to determine the impact stock repurchase on a company’s debt ratio.

The stock repurchase will decrease the company's equity while maintaining their debt obligation. Hence, it will result to an increase in debt ratio. If the corporation decides to use excess cash, the debt obligation will be reduced.
This exercise will determine the effect of stock repurchase on the debt-equity ratio.

### Share repurchase (Share buybacks)

This is where the corporation's shares are previously issued and then reacquired by the issuing entity. These shares are not necessarily canceled, it is just treated as a contra-equity account since it is deducted from the total amount of shareholders’ equity.

These shares are not entitled to receive any forms of dividends and have no right to vote. Moreover, treasury shares are not considered outstanding. Therefore, these shares are not included in earnings per share computation.

The impact of share repurchase on debt ratio will be more clear by learning first what is a debt ratio.

**Debt ratio** - this is commonly used to determine what percentage of assets are financed by entity's through incurring debts.

A debt ratio or **one or more** indicates that majority of the assets were acquired by  incurring debts. While a debt ratio of **less than one** indicates otherwise.

The formula for debt ratio is shown below:

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{Debt ratio} &= \dfrac{\text{Total debts}}{\text{Total assets}}\\[10pt]
\end{aligned}$$

The share repurchase have an impact on debt ratio since it affects the outstanding balance of total assets.

The total assets of the entity are computed as follows:

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{Assets} &= \text{Liabilities} + {\text{Equity}}\\[1pt]
\end{aligned}$$

Whenever the entity reacquired its own shares, the outstanding balance of equity decreases. A decrease on the outstanding balance of equity leads to a decrease on the entity's assets.

A decrease on entity's assets **increase the debt ratio** since the total assets are used as the denominator  of the debt ratio formula.

The debt ratio is also used to determine the ability of the entity's to pay its debts. The entity may repurchase their shares to reduce the outstanding balance of equity so that the debt ratio will increase.

One of the reasons why corporations buy back their previously issued shares is to make their share of stocks financially attractive. The reacquisition of shares decrease the number of outstanding common shares that is used as a denominator in the earnings per share computation. A higher number of shares repurchase will lead to a higher earnings per share and vice versa.
